name: Lucas Nguyen
review_header: A loyal user since 2016: Great performance but a frustrating registration process
review_body: I have been a loyal Vultr customer since 2016, consistently relying on their services to host a wide range of websites. Their platform stands out for its excellent performance-to-price ratio and flexible hourly billing, which makes managing costs for various projects incredibly efficient. The user interface is clean and intuitive, allowing for the rapid deployment of new servers in just a few minutes. Over the years, whenever I've needed help, their support team has proven to be responsive and effective, providing clear solutions to my questions. For core performance, value, and ease of management, Vultr remains a top-tier choice. Despite these strengths, the service is significantly hampered by an overly strict and frustrating account verification process. I have repeatedly encountered issues when setting up accounts for my clients, as my attempts are often flagged for "abuse," likely due to registrations from a shared IP address. This creates an unnecessary obstacle for legitimate, paying users who are ready to use the service. While fraud prevention is important, Vultr's current system is a major deterrent, and they should reconsider this aggressive approach to make their platform more accessible to new, genuine customers.

name: James Clear
review_header: SLA is a Joke – Lost Revenue, Got $20 Credit
review_body: We had a major outage on one of Vultr’s load balancer nodes that lasted over 13 hours, causing serious business damage – lost revenue, bad reviews from customers, and hours of wasted engineering time. The fault was entirely on Vultr’s side, starting right after their maintenance window. From the start, I told their support team that the problem seemed to be with their load balancer nodes. Instead of investigating properly, I got a canned response. If they had taken my report seriously and acted quickly, the downtime could have been reduced from 13 hours to 4–5 hours. Their own system displayed the message: “Some Load Balancer Nodes may be down. Please create a support ticket to fix this issue.” I provided detailed evidence showing our instances were healthy and the fault was within Vultr’s infrastructure. Per their SLA, outages over 7 hours qualify for the highest credit tier — “672 hours (1 month)” — but the fine print means this only applies to the cost of the single affected service item. In our case, that was just the load balancer node, worth about $20. So despite a massive service failure and the real business costs it caused, they hid behind SLA wording and offered the bare minimum. If you’re running anything critical, don’t be fooled by the “100% uptime guarantee.” It’s marketing spin, and when something goes wrong, you’ll get a canned response, slow action, and pocket change for compensation.

name: NE
review_header: Five Years and $2,000/Month Wasted: Vultr's GPU Service is a Nightmare
review_body: As a Vultr customer for five years, during which I've spent approximately $1,500 USD to $2,000 USD every single month on their services, my experience has devolved into utter disappointment and frustration. What began as a promising partnership has become a persistent nightmare, forcing me to now actively plan the migration of all my critical services. The core of my dissatisfaction lies with critical, recurring infrastructure failures, specifically impacting their GPU instances. My GPU server frequently becomes "Unlicensed," rendering it completely useless for extended periods. This isn't an isolated incident; it's a fundamental, persistent flaw within their system that they seem incapable of resolving. Despite their "fixes," the problem always returns. My own investigations consistently point to a deep-seated misconfiguration on Vultr's end, not an issue with my setup. Compounding this technical incompetence is an abysmal support experience. Despite the significant amount of money I invest monthly, I'm consistently met with unhelpful, repetitive responses, a clear lack of understanding of the problem's gravity and persistence, and a general indifference to my critical downtime. I've been repeatedly assured these issues wouldn't reoccur, only to have the exact same problem resurface, proving their assurances are worthless. The real-world impact has been devastating. I recently endured over 22 hours of downtime for one incident, for which I received a meager $50 USD in compensation – a pittance compared to my monthly spend and operational losses. Worse, the server broke down again the very next day with the identical issue, and it has now been down for two full days. This level of unreliability, combined with their inability to provide a permanent solution, is simply unacceptable for a service at this price point. For anyone considering Vultr, especially for mission-critical services or GPU instances, consider this a grave warning. Their infrastructure has severe, recurring flaws, and their support team is ill-equipped to handle serious problems. After five years, my only regret is not leaving sooner. Save yourself the headache and significant financial losses.

name: Nico
review_header: Five Years In, and Deeply Regretting Vultr
review_body: After five years as a Vultr customer, spending around $2,000 monthly, I'm genuinely shocked and deeply disappointed by the recurring issues and the abysmal support I've received. What started as a promising service has devolved into a constant headache, and I'm now actively looking to migrate my services elsewhere. The core of my frustration lies with a persistent and critical GPU licensing issue on my GPU server. This isn't a one-off glitch; it has happened multiple times, causing significant and unacceptable downtime. Each time, my GPU becomes "Unlicensed," rendering my server useless. The "fix" from Vultr has consistently been to tell me to manually recreate the nvidia-gridd.service file, which inexplicably vanishes. I've done this repeatedly. Yet, even when the service file is present, the daemon starts, attempts to acquire a license from nvidialic.vultrlabs.com, and then immediately dies. My own troubleshooting, which frankly, Vultr support should be doing, has revealed the root cause is on their end. My server can connect to their licensing server on port 443, but their server is rejecting the request with a "400 Bad Request" error, stating "The plain HTTP request was sent to HTTPS port." This is a fundamental misconfiguration on Vultr's side, not mine. Despite spending a substantial amount of money monthly, the support experience has been nothing short of infuriating. I'm met with repetitive requests for logs I've already provided, a clear lack of understanding of the problem's persistence, and a general impression that they're more annoyed by my tickets than concerned about resolving a critical, recurring issue. I was even told this wouldn't happen again, yet here we are. This latest incident has cost me 14 hours of critical downtime, and Vultr's inability to provide a permanent solution or even a competent diagnosis is unacceptable. For anyone considering Vultr, especially for GPU instances, be warned: their infrastructure has fundamental flaws, and their support will leave you high and dry. I regret my five-year commitment. Edit: I got compsensated for $150 USD for the downtime of 22 hours. Edit 2: It's the next day, and the GPU is unlicensed again. Same issues. Support was not helpful at all. I feel like they have no understanding about the hardware they are selling.

Then, they kept piling on more questions, making the whole thing way harder than it needed to be. I gave them everything they asked for and then waited almost a full day, just to be told they wouldn’t unblock it. This whole process felt like a huge hassle and really affected my site. I hope Vultr rethinks how they handle these requests to make it easier for people who actually need the support. review_body: We're a small business that runs our large ecommerce website, VOIP PBX (3 instances) and various VPS for Windows instances. We don't remember the last time the server went down. The pricing is excellent, the servers are THE FASTEST and they really offer what they say they will. Any possible negatives? Sort of: - If you are a non-tech person hoping to have someone handhold you through running a server, forget it. Their service department is what they say they include: Only if the server is having issues with networking on performance related to degraded status. They do NOT offer a managed service for basic VPS. And that's OK. This isn't Shopify or NetSuite. I'm not sure where all these negative reviews are coming from. Perhaps people thinking they can run an AI/ML or Minecraft server on a $5 VPS like DO offers and not get white-glove service? I'm not saying Vultr is perfect, no hosting provider is. But normally the thing people want the most is for the server to be FAST and AFFORDABLE. That, Vultr delivers on, period.

review_body: Our web servers suffered a coordinated attack originating from multiple Vultr IP addresses primarily in France. I emailed daily abuse reports identifying the IP addresses and included time-stamped firewall log excerpts for evidence. After a week without any responses, I received a slew of responses all at once, each saying: "Please submit an individual report for each separate IP/domain along with the logs/evidence..." I don't have time to send dozens of separate abuse reports, one per IP address, and Vultr's abuse team is counting on that. I suspect that Vultr's abuse team has a list of "bulletproof hosting" customers against whom they will not take action. If pushed, they create roadblocks like demanding individual, per-IP, abuse reports, knowing that it makes reporting the abuse impractically time-consuming and tedious. I have now blocked all Vultr IPs at our firewall. They no longer have access to any of our web, email, cloud storage, VPN, or other servers. Ask yourself, do you want hosting services from a company whose IP addresses are being blocked for abuse?

name: Dude Dangerous
review_header: Lack of Response to Abuse Reports and Negligence
review_body: I run a niche blockchain network called the D20 Network, which experienced a severe time attack starting on May 28, 2024. The attack originated from six IP addresses managed by Vultr Holdings Corporation. Despite multiple reports and requests for assistance, Vultr's technical support and abuse teams did not respond, allowing the attack to continue and escalate network difficulty to an unmanageable level. This negligence has caused our company an estimated loss of $675,000 due to halted block production, increased operational costs, and damage to our reputation. Furthermore, we have reported this issue to the Carbon County Sheriff’s Department, the FBI, the FTC, and other regulatory bodies. Vultr's failure to enforce their acceptable use policy and manage abuse complaints effectively raises serious concerns about their commitment to customer security and service quality. I urge other potential users to consider these issues before choosing Vultr as their hosting provider.

review_header: I can't get away from these guys

Everything with vultr is easier, the spooling up of a new server, setup of keys, implementing a account wide firewall, monitoring, backups and snapshots. I admin 3 servers, 2 w. plesk and one vpn. it's much easier than the popular ones out there, liquid, fly, digital, etc. I even tried a recent one, SUPER fast on double the ram, just a bit more than vultr- the "3rd" party ratings on this server were something I couldn't ignore- crunchb. did a head to head on a bare install of WP, measured thru all the popular website speed testing- 50% slower than vultr. CONS If you are doing a PBN, footprint would be huge if its all at the same company- any pbn at the same company different IP would be a tell. so thats not reall a con. But the email server set up- that does suck, as you have to use Vultr as your NS. Vultr's NS are not as good or as fast as other dedicated NS providers. This only pertains if you have a Plesk control panel and are hosting your email thru that- otherwise if you are with say, microsoft365 you just make the relevant changes at your domain register or DNS provider same as always. Also I cannot seem to get their apps for VPNs to ever work, so I use a github script to set up wireguard for me on a vanilla ubuntu install.

name: Tawfik Dukhan
review_header: Vultr's Deceptive Marketing and Unjust Fees
review_body: I'm utterly disappointed with the deceitful practices and unjust charges levied by Vultr. My experience has been nothing short of a nightmare, and I feel compelled to share it with others to prevent them from falling victim to this company's misleading offers. Upon signing up, I was enticed by Vultr's alleged $250 credit promotion, only to witness this credit vanish into thin air immediately after making a payment. How could a supposed credit disappear without explanation? To add insult to injury, deploying an instance resulted in direct charges, contrary to the promised credit. When I raised my concerns through the ticketing system, instead of a resolution, I received an unhelpful and dismissive response from the Accounts Team, implying that my debit card was ineligible for promotions, without prior notice or clarification during the signup process. Furthermore, their attempt to manipulate the situation by instructing me to destroy active instances before addressing my request for cancellation is absurd and manipulative. It seems Vultr is more focused on keeping instances active to continue accruing charges rather than addressing legitimate customer grievances. The staff's response lacks empathy and fails to acknowledge the issue of false advertising and unauthorized charges. This is a clear case of misleading customers with fake promises and then conveniently shifting the blame to payment methods to justify their actions. My experience with Vultr has been nothing short of a scam. They use deceptive marketing tactics to lure customers in, only to hit them with unexpected charges and offer zero support when issues arise. It's appalling how they handle customers' concerns and blatantly ignore their responsibility in this matter. I strongly advise against trusting Vultr's promotions or services. Their lack of transparency, unhelpful customer service, and propensity to charge without justification are clear indicators of a company that prioritizes profit over customer satisfaction and honesty. I regret engaging with Vultr and strongly caution others to steer clear of this deceitful company.

name: Nándor Ras
review_header: I should have trusted these reviews…
review_body: I should have trusted these reviews when migrating my email server from Linode to Vultr with my eyes open. The misery at Vultr is indescribable! A YouTube tutorial told me that for setting up a mail server I should go to Vultr but this turned out to be a lie on all sides! The weird thing is that when you create an account you have to add a payment method and they don't accept that you just want to add it. You must necessarily add a minimum amount of $10 to your account before you can even look at the options from which you want to set up your server. The trouble started when it turned out that the e-mail ports seemed to be blocked by default on newly created servers at Vultr and a ticket was submitted for this by default. Nothing crazy about it! Had to go to Linode too. At Linode, the gates were opened within a day without too much fuss. After 2 minutes I already had a response from a "System Administrator" who indicated that the ticket should be forwarded to the account management team for review. About 8 minutes later, however, I got an email back from a Customer Support Representative asking why I wanted the email ports open. After 15 minutes I sent a response explaining that I do not intend to do mass mailing and I only use the mail server for personal purposes. 16 and a half hours later(!!!) I get the response that they don't intend to open the e-mail ports for me after all. The account was too new! I responded within 45 minutes with the message that Vultr then literally turns out to be a useless option for me and I would like a refund of the amount I spent on the server. 2 DAYS AND 4 HOURS LATER I get a response from an account analyst that it is now suddenly possible. "The SMTP block has been lifted" was the message. The only thing I had to do was restart the server after which the lifting of the SMTP block would actually take effect. Pressed the "Restart" button from my control panel: "Error encountered while restarting". I'm not confident I'll get a timely response to this issue from support. I'm going for a Rackspace Email Option at Cloudways! UPDATE: After 15 minutes it is possible to start the server again and the blockage has indeed been removed. All in all a very bad start with Vultr!

name: Mike
review_header: Bait and switch, bad business practices, dubious no refund policy
review_body: tl;dr I got bait and switched by Vultr vps. I was invoiced out of the blue for features(storage) that were always free in an inactive account(no instances) months after they were destroyed because they decided to start billing their entire customer base for an existing free feature. Classic. Vultr's business practices are questionable in how they get your money(they aren't really as cheap as their advertising makes it seem when you sign up). And apparently they don't "do" refunds. Huge red flag there. As other reviewers have said, you should probably stay away. There are a lot of CAPS LOCK segments in their TOS that seem to be them shouting at you ungrateful customers to shut up and because we've already taken your money. lol The funny part is they also shout that the parts that they are shouting might be illegal, and in that case the consumer protection law prevails over these intimidating shouty bits. Bonus points if you can find that statement in the TOS on their website vultr.com My interaction with customer service has been poor as you might have seen from other reviews. It seems they don't actually read your e-mail as they seem to miss many of the points of your tickets and reply with canned responses. I don't know if this is a language thing or they're outsourcing the support. This of course ends up being a time waster for everyone. Basically they tick every check box for a very bad IT provider, except one. Their stuff works last I used it. It's nothin fancy but when I was using it seems to work okay for light application non-production or critical use. But there seems to be a lot of 1 star reviews about their reliability, so take my 2 stars with a grain of salt. Whatever you do don't kid yourself, take Vultr for what it is, a Florida company, a bottom market segment operator hustling for customers with a classic low pricing model. But your instance might go down and you'll get that nagging feeling in your stomach that you're overpaying when your bill comes in. They're a bunch Vultrs I tell ya lol. On a side note I feel like mistakes where made when choosing a name, but I really hope they finish the change to The Constant Company and leave all this unpleasantness behind them so they can hit those numbers and get that sweet VC/exit. Shop around, there are better deals with better companies and good free trials etc. You don't want to be sharing a node with some low segment penny pincher hosting who knows who or what. I'm currently still trying to get a refund. I'll let ya know how that goes. I don't exactly have high soaring hopes.

name: Andrew Hawken
review_body: I have enjoyed a great service with Vultr since 2016. No issues, everything has been great. A couple of days ago I submitted my very first support ticket regarding their DNS service. I just wanted the serial corrected (it was showing as 0) on one of my zones. That’s all. I spelled out the problem very clearly. I had to educate the technician that picked up the issue that I was using Vultr DNS, not my own (upon them telling me it was my problem). Why I had to do this I have no idea. A quick lookup on the domain would have shown that information, or maybe they could have viewed the domain on IntoDNS.com, using the link I provided in my opening post. My issue was never resolved, with various technicians telling me ‘everything is fine or if you want to update the serial, deploy your own DNS servers.' I'm not sure what is so hard about updating the serial on a zone file. Perhaps if they were a little more transparent with me on the why, or just looked into the problem instead of trying to close the ticket as quickly as possible, I might be a little more understanding. I’ll remain with Vultr, but I’ll never ask for technical support again.

review_header: Everything is automated, runs smoothly and is of great value.
review_body: Honestly have nothing to complain about. If anything, I love this service. - Neatly designed control panel with all the features I could want/need: instance summaries, resource usage, backups, DDoS protection on/off, snapshots, DNS, settings (IPv4/IPv6, private networking, rDNS, Firewall, Hostname, Plan, etc.), block storage, etc, etc. - Custom OSes supported. (Upload your own ISO.) - KVM style console access to your VM. Love this. Essential for custom OS installation but also very handy if your VM loses internet access (misconfiguration/other) and you need to bring it back up. - VMs are quick and easy to deploy. - Everything runs like clockwork. - IRC bouncers allowed. - Good value. - Charged by the hour. I love that last feature. If you mess something up in your VM, with a lot of the other hosts you got to start over and pay another overlapping monthly fee. Not with Vultr. I messed up my custom OS install, deleted the instance and re-installed. Only lost a few cents, not a whole month's worth of fees (~$25). ** I'm not encouraging carelessness but that it's good to have peace of mind of knowing you won't lose a lot of money for a mistake that requires redeployment of an instance.

Now, if that were it I would give it maybe 3 or even 4 stars as all issues are possible to deal with without having to deal with Vultr Support (Which is an oxymoron). BUT! Vultr decided to violently shut it down because they THOUGHT that was my instance was compromised and doing DoS attacks, which was not the case. At first I explained the situation, waiting a day and resumed operations. Then they shut it down AGAIN, this time CORRUPTING THE DISK! Worse yet, it was done by their system administrator (Joshua Brand). The inhouse system administrator is incompetent. What does this say about the company? I was able to save the day with fsck.
